I'll have a stab at it..

Linked Data is=A0concerned=A0with using hypertext=
 to construct an
intelligible=A0graph from the web that is publicly availab=
le and can be
analysed/queried.

REST is concerned with using hypertext to =
expose applications so that
their evolution can be managed efficiently over=
 time.

Basically, they use hypertext as a means to different ends. REST is=

about directing the flow of the web's applications, LD is about
establishi=
ng a structure to the web's data.

One important LD-related technology is R=
DF, although it's not the only
way to do LD it does seem to have unearthed =
some of the fundamental
differences between LD and REST, so I'll share my p=
erspective on that:

RDF, in the quest for web-intelligibility, does not se=
em to cope very
well with the ambiguous and messy reality of The Web. This =
has led to
a lot of controversy and demands from the RDF community for solu=
tions
to problems that apparently don't exist for REST or anyone else
outsi=
de of 'RDF land' - a good example of a this is range-14. This has
produced =
lots of long-winded and confused philosophical debate, but
one of my favour=
ite insights is a post from 2002 by Roy:

http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Publ=
ic/www-tag/2002Jul/0090.html

Cheers,
Mike
